pros: Great network & learning opportunity Flexible environment, different settings
cons: Lower salary Difficult to get hired. Highly sought after job

review_title: Great atmosphere of people, nice work culture
job_title: Patient Care Associate in Charlestown, MA
pros: Coworkers are friendly, nice helping work culture
cons: Very physical, a lot of lifting

review_title: Not something I would do long term
job_title: Patient Care Associate (PCA) in Cambridge, MA
pros: Benefits are a 10/10. Great 401k plan and health insurance. If you love helping people you will love seeing the patients smile after helping them! You won't get bored!
cons: At this facility the nurses don't tend to help the PCAs, 90% are lazy. Being a PCA is stressful on the body, very physically demanding. It's sad because I really liked helping the patients. If the nurses had helped more I would have stayed but as a PCA you do more work than the nurses. Even if they are in the room with the patient, instead of them helping you with the patient for just 3 min they make you look for someone else to help. This was the main reason I left. The workload was too much for the pay

pros: good benefits and great facilities
cons: Not as much research-physician interaction as you would think

pros: good environment and supportive staff
cons: slightly limited potential for growth

pros: The people, are above all the best part. I never had issues with anyone in my own department, it might be a different story in others. But for me the people I worked with were the main reason for coming to work.
cons: Exhausting work, which goes without saying. We were always short staffed and you were always asked if you could work overtime.

review_title: less competitive pay, no parking for day shift, illegal pay cuts
job_title: Patient Care Assistant (PCA) in Boston, MA
pros:
-learn a lot (rehab devices, g tubes, trachs) 
-fellow nurses are great and helpful
cons:
-pay is less than other boston hospitals so many staff leave after 1 year 
-full time nurses/staff don't clock in/out so a lot of the time, they stay late charting and still don't get paid 
-lots of healthstream modules but unwilling to pay you for your time doing them outside of work (literally no time during work) 
-many nurses end up not getting full breaks 
-residents don't seem to care if you're patient is abusive or hitting you 
-no parking for day shift unless you're full-time and sign up on a waitlist so only public transportation 
-hospital campaigned AGAINST safe ratios during 2018's Massachusetts ballot question

review_title: Good place to start for new grads

review_title: SRB is a great place to learn, could be a lot better

cons: Fast-paced, stressful. High nurse:patient ratios, making it difficult to find time for breaks. One supervisor constantly talks trash and places blame for everything on everyone else from the prior shift. Poor pay, and it's salary.

pros: Everyone is really nice and exceptionally helpful.

cons: You experience minimal flexibility with work/life balance.

pros: Good benefits, nice staff, and pay is decent. Will help to continue education.
cons: Patient ratio at Brighton location 1:7-12. Short staff. People always leave every few months. No respiratory therapist, limited phlebotomist, no iv nurse, and nurses have to do most things. The pay is salary. Preceptors don’t get paid and no extra for floating. No nurse educator, the staff educator teaches most of the stuff. Push meds in a big cart. Don’t follow scope of practice here.

job_title: Staff RN in East Sandwich, MA
pros: Great benefits, co-workers, everyone is looking out for the patients.
cons: Staff very resistant to any change. Management under values staff. Always under staffed. Great place to be a patient but not to be a nurse or an assistant.

review_title: My 2nd CNA/PCA job with little complaints
job_title: Patient Care Assistant (PCA) in Boston, MA
pros:
-building is fairly new, modern, and beautiful sights in every pt room
-learning opportunities
-a lot of PCAs end up being RNs here
-one of the best rehab hospitals in the country
-I make about 20 an hour as per diem (we need to normalize discussions with pay)
cons:
-you have to sign up for a waitlist if you want parking! there is no parking otherwise so good luck (if you're per diem like me, after 3pm parking is only $5 then)
-as per diem, you float all the time so some units get upset if you don't do things how they like it...it varies on every unit
-morning shift is more difficult but less pay; you are expected to give everyone a shower while not taking up therapy's schedule
-hoyer lifts are a 2 person transfer only but it's hard to get help anyways

pros: Supportive coworkers, excellent learning experiences, good reference to have
cons: Administrative based, limited communication, restricted growth opportunity

review_title: Never bored but pay could be better
pros: Very good team effort on the units. Patient cases can very interesting with nutrition playing a large role.
cons: Pay could be better for the amount of work. Often working over hours with no extra pay.

pros: Great exposure to many different patient populations
cons: Demanding work environment, poor pay

review_title: Patients and coworkers are amazing, but very underpaid

cons: Very underpaid, often over worked, limited/restricted clinical advancement opportunities— high turn over rate of employees

pros: Short distance from my house

review_title: Great place to start nursing career
pros: Great benefits such 403b retirement savings, tuition reimbursement
cons: The hourly rate as a new grad is not great compared to other MGB hospitals

pros:
-Incredible experience. Patient acuity is high and you see patients with a wide variety of conditions. --Nurses are allowed to do procedures that are done by MDs elsewhere, such as wound vac's, complicated dressings, peritoneal dialysis, etc.
-Willingness and proven history of hiring and training new grads.
cons:
-Low pay. 1-2% merit raises per year, no yearly bonuses.
-Inability to retain good employees. High turnover rate.
-Unsafe staffing ratios despite persistent complaints from staff.
-High acuity with insufficient resources.
-Medical equipment are old and always broken. Basic things like vital sign machines are not guaranteed to be available when needed.
-One physician covers the entire hospital overnight. 
-Unrealistic expectations from management for RNs. They seem to be out of touch with the work load of RNs and with bedside nursing. They expect the work quality of a 1:3 staffing ratio but then implements a ratio of 1:5-8.
-Alarms from monitors and equipment on the unit are out of control. Patients and staff alike are annoyed by all the distracting noises, but MDs and management are unwilling to do anything about it for liability reasons. It doesn't make sense to give medication for insomnia and then have crazy alarms ringing throughout the night.
-It bears repeating: terrible staffing ratios.

review_title: Pharmacist Intern at Spaulding Rehabilitation Hospital
pros: Great pharmacy staff and work environment
cons: Pay is little low compared to other companies in the area

pros: Nice building and patient rooms all private.
cons: Poor staffing....low salary compared to other Boston hospitals.

pros: Good place to have a job
cons: Some times hard to get to

pros: Close leadership team, great science
cons: High expectations despite small team

job_title: Physical Therapy Technician in Salem, MA
pros: Great company and great benefits.
cons: No growth opportunities available for this position.

pros: Good place to start out as a new grad nurse
cons: young staff, understaffing, low base pay, poor management

job_title: Patient Care Assistant (PCA) in Boston, MA
pros: Respect and care for their workers' wellbeing
cons: There is none to think of.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Charlestown, MA
pros: coworkers, nurses, patients, patient family, work
cons: parking, parking, parking parking, parking

pros: The facility has a great reputation
cons:
Constantly felt like I was being looked down upon by nurses and other staff members. Very disorganized.  The head nurse of the facility was incredibly rude to me once because she apparently had no idea I was coming or who I was (it was my first night working there).  I never really felt comfortable working there, which is why I didn't work very often.
It's not the most exciting job by nature, but sometimes I felt like me and the patient were forgotten by the nurse (I realize they're busy, but you need to at least come in and talk to the patient, let them know when you'll be in to give them their morning meds, etc.  Otherwise they often become much more agitated).

review_title: I did not enjoy working here
job_title: Physical Therapist in East Sandwich, MA
pros: Great knowledgeable coworkers who are always willing to help. Good communication within healthcare team.
cons: Forced to work one weekend a month and holidays, unsafe work conditions with regular injuries, high turnover, low pay, hourly employees pressured into clocking out early and working through lunch

review_title: It was very rewording, and beneficial. I gained a lot of experience on IV preparation and patient care.
pros: The work environment is very good. People feel proud to be part of this hospital. It provide full support to their employees in professional front it has many branches across MA.The Spaulding Rehabilitation Hospital is a 132-bed rehabilitation teaching hospital located in Boston, Massachusetts. It is a part of  Partners Health Care which is a non-profit organization that owns several hospitals in Massachusetts, primarily in the Boston area. Massachusetts General Hospital and Brigham and Women's Hospital founded the organization in 1994.so I have good opportunity to show my talent.
cons: Transportation is a challenge, because there is no public transportation access, you must own a car.

pros:
Beautiful waterfront location which is great for inpatient recovery.
Spaulding Rehab Hospital is  ranked #5 in the nation!
Great co-workers, dedicated PT/OT/SPEECH  for patients.
cons:
Don't get taken in by the beautiful bldg & waterfront location.
Understaffed and high turnover due to overload & stress.
Management cares only about "numbers" & "stats". 
David Storto & upper management have no clue about the hard work that goes on in the trenches.....again, only concerned with numbers & stats.
Poor outpatient management, with lack of planning. 
Shuffle the staff around, instead of addressing the REAL problems.

pros:
The new hire program is great. Orientation is about 2-3 days of in class learning, then you get five days on the floor with another pca. People are generally very nice and willing to help out when needed. A lot of chances to pick up hours/ OT.
Per diem only requires that you pick up three shifts per month; one has to be a weekend. Great for a nursing student! Most of the nurses are willing to explain what is going on
cons:
Negative people of some floors that are unwilling to help out 
People tends to stick to there clicks.

pros: Supportive staff that is term oriented. Benefits are good. Evening and weekend parking heavily discounted for staff. Great location.
cons: One bad apple can spoil the whole bunch. Sometimes like most hospitals you have to work with someone that lacks empathy for their patients and are lazy. Management has a poor record of dealing with these rotten apples. Day shift parking is very expensive. Poor hourly wages compared to other hospitals the city of Boston.

review_title: Very little loyalty to long term employees
pros: State of the art facility.
cons: No loyalty to long tern employees.  Bringing in the cheap, inexperienced help.   Pay is not competitive.  Management uses the excuse, "We are a rehab, not an acute so we pay less."  However nurse : patient ratio is much higher than how the acutes staff.

review_title: Great place but has its flaws
pros: Great facility, patient population, good benefits and matching retirement
cons: Lowest starting salary of all the boston area hospitals for physical therapy.  Nurses are paid similarly and because of this there is high turnover and inconsistencies for your patients.  To get a promotion requires you to write essays and attend classes to become an 'advanced clinician' which can be rejected.  Spaulding is the only facility I have worked at that does this.

review_title: It's a fair starting point to a career in nursing.
pros: By working at Spaulding you get to see patients improve and go home; it's very satisfying.  Even more incredible, you're able to make lasting relationships with your patients because of the long period they stay on your floor.
cons: As a nurse, it's very difficult to work in a hospital where the primary purpose is therapy.  It's difficult to know that your patients often times develop better relationships with their therapists than with you.

pros: Good benefits, adequate pay.  Great network for focusing on education and learning.  I had found good mentorship with the more experienced PT's, of which there are plenty.
cons: As with all positions, make sure it's a good cultural fit with your supervisor at the specific location you will be working.  Plus the documentation system is a beast.

pros: Beautiful facility & wonderful coworkers. If you're specifically looking for a career in rehab this would be the best place to work
cons: Parking is a nightmare, rarely offer 12 hour shifts, base pay is very low compared to the amount of work nurses provide, unsafe nurse to patient ratios, high turnover rate, cafeteria food is terrible, no room for future growth

pros: Great patient and staff relationships! Part of the Partners corporation and they take care of their employees! They pay their employees above average.
cons: Management is very disorganized, they need work at treating their employees fairly. One of the downsides is that the nurses do have a difficult getting jobs at non-rehabilitation based hospitals.

review_title: Good place to begin, pay is too low to stay
pros: Partners Benefits are very good. You will be exposed to a wide range of complicated patients, which will give you the skills to handle almost any type of patient later in your career.
cons: Getting to Inman Square and finding parking is challenging.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Cambridge, MA
pros:
good exp. as a new RN in need of a first job at the time, however, very little support at this time amongst staff as nurses, CNAs, providers are all so busy with patient care ,etc.
decent pay
cons: schedule difficult, rotating shifts, not enough nursing or support staff for patient load and acuity

pros: Amazing place to learn as a new grad. Lots of autonomy. We do all our own IVs, blood draws (on eve/night shifts), wound dressings, etc. Working with vented patients, VADs, administering chemo. Staffing has gotten a lot better.
cons: Staffing is not always as good as it needs to be. Sometimes we have up to 5 patients on days. Management. Staff turnover.

pros: Good mission driven organization that really cares about the patients.
cons: Mentoring and management training could use some help as you work up through the ranks. Sometimes managers forget that helping their subordinates is part of their job.

pros: The staff are very professional overall, working as a team with patient focus. Management has an open door policy and is generally responsive to the needs of staff and patients.
cons: HR can be very slow with the hiring process. Shift to shift relationships could be better sometimes but that is common.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistance in Cambridge, MA
pros: It's all dependent on who you work with. Benefits, good long term employer.
cons: Large company issues, management compromises employee and patient safety for budgetary cuts.

pros: Spaulding provided wonderful care through a Multi discilpinary approach in medical setting .It was supportive and respecful to staff in producing good outcomes for staff.
cons: Spaulding was in need of updates . For example no private rooms was a disadvantage to some patients .

cons: They sitll only do 8 hour shifts, and they're very weird about use of earned time, and it can feel like you're jumping through hoops to get your weekends off.

review_title: Good place to start a nursing career

cons: Staff issues, which cause high turnover rates, which cause more staff issues. Not a lot of room for career advancement.

pros: Good colleagues, respect from MDs, CMs; challenging patient population; continuing education; better pay and benefits due to union within hospital

review_title: It's like a farm system for bigger hospitals

pros: Some of the co-workers are friendly and willing to help.
cons: Administration is not helpful and will throw you under the bus to save themselves.  It is also part of a huge management group and they treat you like you are just a number who is replaceable.

pros: Treat staff well, good morale, great benefits and everyone is very friendly and caring.  Staff take pride in what they do - here to take care of the patients.
cons: Limited room for upward mobility due to small size of facility.

pros: Awesome team, state of the art facility, opportunity to grow
cons: I did not find any cons but I was there only for a short period of time. It look like a wonderful place to work for.

pros: Coworkers are awesome people to work with!
cons: Upper management does not back you. Poor performers get rewarded and hard workers don't. Do as I say not as I do! Boston site is in a tough location to drive to.

pros: Great people to work with who are dedicated to their patients; rehab; Excellent environment to work in..
cons: Parking is unavailable for commuters from the tristate area

pros: Excellent work atmosphere with great co-workers.  Very friendly and inspiring.
cons: Company constantly expanding.  Do not want to get lost.

pros: Close to home & a beautiful new state of the art facility. Also great coworkers & team players who deliver excellent care to the patients needs.
cons: Only working on call 7 perdium.

pros: Good experience if you're looking to do rehab, they are one of the bests
